Fig. 3 The evolution of water in the effluent during specified conductivity experiments. Fig. 4 TGA data during heating of Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ in humid oxygen. Fig. 5 Comparison between the variation of conductance as a function of reciprocal temperature for various argon runs, as function of the sample history: DAr-III- before oxygen treatment; DAr-IV- after oxygen treatment; HAr- humid argon. Fig. 6 Capacitance as a function of temperature for dry argon- I (DAr-I), dry argon-III (DAr-III), dry O2 (DOx-I) and humid O2 (HOx). Fig. 7 Conductance as a function of reciprocal temperature for humid argon, C3H6:air (1:10), (C3H6/air), dry argon- (DAr-V), dry O2-II (DOx-II). Fig. 8 Comparison between variation of conductance in C3H6:air (1:10) (C3H6/air), dry argon-V (DAr-V), dry O2-II (DOx-II) and in CO:air (1:20) mixture (CO/air). Fig. 9 Capacitance as a function of temperature for (C3H6/air) C3H6:air (1:10), dry argon-V (DAr-V), dry O2-II (DOx-II) and CO:air (1:20) mixture (CO/air). Fig. 10 TGA variation on heating the used Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ in air (after flow blockage). (The dotted line indicates the rate of temperature variation). Murgulescu” Institute of Physical Chemistry of the Romanian Academy, Splaiul Independentei 20277208 BucharestRomania b Department of Chemical Engineering, Bradford UniversityWest Yorkshire, BD7 1DPUK * Corresponding author. The AC electrical properties of the mixed conducting oxide Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ at 1592Hz have been monitored during in-situ temperature programmed exposure to a sequence of dry and/or humid gaseous atmospheres between ambient and 400°C. TGA data was correlated with the electrical measurements. Dry oxygen had little effect. Humidity resulted in a significant increase in conductance and capacitance in argon but not in oxygen. Changes in conductance and capacitance arise from changes in both surface conductance and surface dipoles during chemisorption and reaction processes. Following n-type behaviour, in both propylene:air and CO:air treatments, the conductance was increased, indicating reduction of the catalyst surface. Very low conversion (<5%) was obtained for propylene (mainly to carbon dioxide), while a higher conversion (maximum of about 97%) was achieved for CO which indicates that Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ could be a possible catalyst to control pollution. Keywords Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ Catalyst Temperature programmed reaction Propylene oxidation Carbon monoxide oxidation Conductivity 1 Introduction Li x Ni y Co1−y O2−δ non-stoichiometric materials are mixed conductors having a layered structure through which alkali ions can move with relative ease and have been widely studied for their potential as positive electrode materials in Li batteries (e.g. [1]) and also have potential as catalysts for oxidation reactions. The effect of stoichiometry on the stability and AC electrical properties of pellets of these materials and their composites with Al2O3 at elevated temperatures has previously been examined [2]. Optimum stability and maximum AC conductivity in Ar was obtained for Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ . This compound has the highest loss tangent at room temperature (0.45), typical for dielectric response governed by dipole relaxation from dipoles arising from imperfections in the structure of the material. At 523°C, the loss tangent was 24, a value typical of dielectric losses from free rather than bound thermally activated charges [2]. At low frequencies, particularly at high temperatures, the frequency dependence of conductivity was negligible, indicating that thermally activated charge carriers dominate the AC behaviour [2]. Complex impedance diagrams examined showed a single or partial semicircle at low temperature, with a large angle of tilt to the real axis, typical for materials of mixed or principally electronic conductivity [2]; thus, separate loss processes relating to bulk or grain boundary phenomena could not be distinguished. The dynamic analysis of effluent species (using the multiple-ion monitoring facility of a quadrupole mass spectrometer) with temperature linearly increasing with time for two reactions, carbon dioxide hydrogenation (250°C to 600°C) and the oxidative coupling of methane (400°C to 800°C) have previously been examined [3, 4]. The AC electrical characteristics of the catalyst pellet between 100Hz and 1MHz were simultaneously monitored in situ and a clear correlation between catalytic behaviour and electrical properties was obtained. The effect of atmosphere (CO2, H2) was found to be rather complex up to 370°C. This was partly considered to be due to the production of some steam and CO from the reverse water–gas-shift reaction. However, no irreversible change occurred at this temperature. In this current work, the electrical and catalytic properties for C3H6 and CO oxidation in a lower temperature range (up to 400°C) has been studied at low frequency (1592Hz). The variations in electrical properties of powdered Li x Ni y Co1−y O2−δ have been monitored in situ between room temperatures and 400°C using a specially constructed cylindrical cell, reported elsewhere [5]for a sequence of different atmospheres. The effects of humidity (in argon and oxygen) have also been examined. Correlations with weight changes were performed using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). Some new facets of the catalytic mechanisms have been exposed and further steps taken to establish the links between the electrical properties of conducting mixed oxides and their catalytic behaviour as advocated by Gellings and Bouwmeester [6]. The additional coupling of electrical and thermogravimetric techniques is relatively new in catalysis (e.g. [7, 8]) and is worthy of further exploration. 2 Experimental method Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ powder with a BET surface area of about 5m2/g was synthesised by the solid state reaction method described previously [2]. About 1.5cm3 of catalyst grains (0.2–0.6mm diameter) were placed between two cylindrical coaxial tantalum electrodes in a special glass reactor providing in situ electrical conductivity and catalytic activity measurements as described elsewhere [5]. The surface conditioning was obtained by submitting the sample to three programmed heating cycles between 20°C and 400°C at 2°C/min. in dry argon (I to III); this treatment was followed by heating–cooling cycles in dry oxygen and in humid oxygen (2.5mg H2O/l gas) respectively; finally the experiment in dry argon (taken as a reference state) was repeated (Ar-IV). During these pre-catalytic experiments the composition of the effluent was continuously monitored by gas chromatography. Following these series, programmed heating cycles were performed in atmospheres of humid argon, propylene+air, dry argon (V), dry oxygen and carbon monoxide+air; electrical conductance, capacitance and catalytic activity were also simultaneously measured. In each case, after the programmed heating, the sample was allowed to cool at about 10°C/min. in the same atmosphere. In the GC analysis water could be detected up to 100ppm (with an error of about 5%). Small fluctuations in water content in the effluent were observed and could partly have been caused by some retention on the pipes during analysis; this could also contribute to differences observed for the temperature of onset of water retention, with respect to TGA information. The AC electrical conductance and parallel capacitance were measured in situ by using a semi-automatic precision bridge TESLA BM484 at a frequency of 1592Hz. Thermogravimetric (TGA) investigations between ambient and 400°C were conducted on about 30mg of powdered catalyst in an aluminium crucible using a computer controlled Shimadzu TGA-50 thermobalance. Atmospheres of argon, air and oxygen (both dry and humid) (with gas flow rates of 60ml/min) were used in the same order as employed in the conductivity experiments with 2°C/min for the heating rate and about 10°C/min for the cooling rate. A mixture of propylene–air (1:10 unless otherwise mentioned) at a total flow rate of 60cm3/min was passed over the catalyst bed, and the catalytic activity was measured between 250°C and 400°C. Propylene oxidation was then tested for 10h under stationary conditions for a variety of contact times and ratios of the reactants. This was followed by testing the catalyst for CO oxidation using the same flow rate. Gas analysis for evaluating catalytic activity was performed by periodic sampling during temperature programmed heating in the conductivity experiments and/or after temperature stabilisation for a longer period at specified temperatures. The product analysis (CO2, water, propylene, acrolein and saturated aldehydes) was performed by gas chromatography, using two parallel 1.5m columns (Porapak Q and molecular sieves 5A). 3 Results and discussion XRD spectra of the Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ compound were presented elsewhere [2]. The crystal patterns are similar to those of LiCoO2, reported by Zhecheva and Stoyanova [9]. Substitution of Ni for 50 at% Co in the crystal does not result in a change in the structural framework. An additional peak (d=2.072) was considered to indicate the presence of some NiO impurity in the sample. This was also shown in other 50 at% Ni preparations, suggesting a limited capacity of the lattice for accommodating Ni ions. TGA measurements on a fresh sample of material showed that some weight was lost during initial heating in argon and continued to be lost during the cooling stage with a total loss of about 0.28%. The loss of weight occurred in several steps: a rapid one (up to 60–80°C), a very slow one (80–300°C) and a much faster one (300–400°C) (Fig. 1 ). Simultaneous GC analysis during the conductivity measurements showed that this weight loss reflected mainly the loss of adsorbed moisture in the sample, almost all of which was lost during the first cycle; on second and third cycles in argon, losses were much reduced and similar in nature. These results correlate well with the change in conductance-reciprocal temperature curves (Fig. 2 ) which show substantially larger conductances at the lower temperatures up to about 225°C for the initial experiment in argon. The conductivity pattern also revealed some different phases as the temperature increased (up to 60°C, 60–140°C, 140–225°C, 225–300°C and 300–400°C). After three cycles, the curves become essentially reproducible, with an activation energy of about 0.45eV between 240°C and 370°C. Analysis of the effluent during the temperature programmed conductivity experiments showed that water was steadily lost up to 140°C during the first argon cycle and thereafter decreased (Fig. 3 ); during the third argon cycle negligible amounts of moisture were produced. The loss of water coincides with the observed decrease of conductivity. The initial capacitance values increased from about 0.1nF at room temperature to about 3nF at 400°C with a shallow superimposed peak at about 150°C during the drying out period. Subsequent capacitance characteristics in argon were smoother and very similar with a final capacitance at 400°C of about 2.5nF. 3.1 Effects of oxygen and humidity Subsequent to the three cycles in dry argon, a dry oxygen atmosphere was used, followed by humid oxygen, dry argon and finally humid argon. TGA revealed a substantial weight increase on contacting with dry oxygen at room temperature; on heating, most of this weight gain was lost up to 120°C. Continuing the heating, weight changes in dry oxygen were erratic and slight (<0.1%). On cooling, a slight increase of weight was observed below 80°C. This illustrated the capacity of the material to adsorb oxygen at low temperatures. Thus, the decrease of weight on heating in dry oxygen can be attributed to the loss of low temperature pre-adsorbed oxygen. Room temperature adsorption of humid oxygen (TGA data) occurred in two stages: 0.12% and 0.055%, respectively; about 0.15% weight was lost on heating up to 100°C (Fig. 4 ) with a further loss on cooling up to 150°C; thereafter a gain in weight of about 0.12% was observed. Hence, more water from the humid atmosphere had been adsorbed at lower temperatures. This water was found to be released when the sample was reheated and cooled in dry argon, with a loss of about 0.1% up to 100°C, and subsequent similar loss between 300°C and 400°C, (0.29% total loss). It is possible that a further surface dehydroxylation had occurred. Apart from producing a slight decrease in conductance, dry oxygen was found to have little effect on the conductance–temperature characteristics (Fig. 2); humid oxygen produced a slight increase in the conductance at room temperature. Above 60°C, humid oxygen also had little effect other than to produce slightly lower values and some fluctuations between ambient and 200°C. Above 230°C, the conductivity characteristics in dry argon and oxygen are almost identical, except for slightly higher conductances in humid oxygen (Fig. 2). Analysis of the effluent in humid oxygen showed that even if still present, moisture in the effluent is much diminished with respect to the initial value up to about 80°C; above 250°C the water content is again diminished due to some retention by the catalyst (Fig. 3) showing good correlation with the TGA results (Fig. 4). This behaviour corresponds to the slight increase of conductivity at high temperature. The following cycle in dry argon (IV) gave characteristics close to the previous cycle in argon (III), slightly decreased conductivity at higher temperatures, (this indicating a slight oxidation of the sample). In contrast, humid argon resulted in a significant increase in conductance at lower temperatures up to 225°C (Fig. 5 ). The apparent differences in the temperature at which the onset of water retention occurs could partly arise from differences in location of the thermocouples in the electrical conductivity experiments (temperature being taken as the average value from an external-controlling thermocouple and one located in the centre of the catalyst bed) and TGA set-up (located on the plate supporting the crucible). In the electrical conductivity measurement, a much larger amount of material is used, hence the retention of water appears earlier, (i.e. at a lower temperature). TGA measurements indicate (Fig. 4) that this starts around 300°C. On the other hand, TGA gives the total variation of weight (losses and gains) which also includes effects from oxygen desorption/adsorption. Consequently, desorption of oxygen can compensate for water retention, so the TGA may also appear to be delayed. Fig. 6 shows the capacitance characteristic in dry oxygen to be close to that in dry argon, whilst in humid oxygen, oscillatory behaviour occurred between 140°C and 230°C (conductance values were also erratic up to this temperature) and thereafter the values increased slightly above those in dry oxygen. On repeating the experiment in dry argon (DAr-IV), characteristics close to that in DAr-III were obtained. Analysis of the effluent in the conductivity experiments in dry argon IV showed no water (within the limits of GC detection) up to 360°C but some oxygen. However, the following cycle in humid argon resulted in a slight reduction of capacitances with rather erratic behaviour above 227°C. This observation is the reverse of the effect of humidity on the conductance values, and highlights the complex behaviour of moisture trapped in the smallest pores of the material, the erratic behaviour possibly arising from pockets of moisture jumping from one position to another. The marked difference in the effect of humidity in argon and oxygen atmospheres suggests that water and oxygen may compete/cooperate for adsorption at the same sites. Adsorption of oxygen follows the sequence, (1) O 2+e⇌O − 2+e⇌2O −+2e⇌2O 2− This will result in a decrease in the electronic conductivity of the surface. Water adsorption occurs (i) as molecular, coordinatively-bound species at low temperatures and (ii) dissociatively, on anion vacancy-lattice oxygen pairs, (with a hydroxyl group located on an anion vacancy and a proton located on the neighbouring oxygen ion) at higher temperatures. This type of adsorption must be greater after slight reduction of the surface has occurred (particularly after heating in a dry inert atmosphere). Hence at low temperatures, molecularly adsorbed water may replace weakly adsorbed surface oxygen, also acting as a vehicle for the movement of protons [10]. At high temperatures, cooperative adsorption of oxygen and water may result in increased surface hydroxylation and consequently increased contribution of mobile protons to conduction/catalysis in a humid oxygen containing atmosphere by a Grotthus type mechanism [10]. Hence, at low temperatures, in the presence of humid oxygen, the measured change in electrical conductance is an averaged result of oxygen adsorption (decrease in electronic conduction) and increased proton conduction (provided by molecularly adsorbed water); this is further demonstrated by the larger effect of water on conductivity in the absence of oxygen (humid Ar experiment, Fig. 5). Such possibilities could have significant effects on the product distribution in oxidation reactions. It would also be expected, (for a given total flow rate and temperature), that the ratio of fuel to oxygen or air in the feedstock would have a significant effect on the product distribution. In their DC electrical investigations on the p-type semiconductor LaNiO3 for various catalytic oxidation reactions, Ling et al. [11]also found that water vapour (a product of the reactions) competed for active sites with the reactants during oxidation and could act as an inhibitor. 3.2 Catalytic behaviour In this report, the potential activity of the Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ compound as an oxidation catalyst for propylene and carbon monoxide oxidation has been studied. In the presence of oxygen (or air) propylene can be selectively oxidised to partial oxidation compounds, e.g. acrolein, via: (2) C3H6+O2 →C3H4O+H2O Other parallel oxidation reactions occur simultaneously, the most important one being the thermodynamically favoured total oxidation of propylene: (3) C3H6 + 9 2 O 2→3CO2+3H2O and also the oxidation of the product: (4) C3H4O+3O2 →3CO2+2H2O Selectivity for partial oxidation depends on the balance between the rate of partial oxidation product formation and that of total oxidation. If acrolein desorption is too slow, part of it will decompose. According to the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [12], hydrocarbon oxidation on oxide catalysts occurs on lattice oxygen sites, while gaseous oxygen when present in the feed, restores the oxidation level of the reduced catalyst. Whilst lattice oxygen is generally considered to be involved in the partial oxidation of propylene, the nature of the oxygen producing deep oxidation remains subject to debate. Both lattice oxygen and the more reactive, electrically charged, adsorbed oxygen species can be involved [13]. This is also true for carbon monoxide oxidation: (5) CO+ 1 2 O 2⇌CO 2 The effects on the temperature programmed conductance of the propylene/air (1:10) mixture, followed by dry argon V, dry oxygen and the CO/air (1:20) mixture are shown in Fig. 7 Fig. 8 . In both cases of the reducing gas/air mixture the conductance values are significantly higher (up to a factor of about 10 at 400°C) than in the previous argon and oxygen pre-treatment atmospheres. Closer to ambient, the greatly increased values of conductance reflect the strong chemisorption of gaseous species. Dipoles will be formed close to the surface and at 1592Hz significant dipole relaxation losses may occur, which result in a strong frequency dependence of the AC conductance, which is virtually independent of temperature [14]. Such effects have also been observed during temperature programmed reactions coupled to changes in AC characteristics over a wide range of frequency between 100Hz and 1MHz for the same material [3, 4]. Since oxygen alone has little effect, the strong increase in the room temperature conductance must be associated with a reducing effect of the propylene, which would indicate that the material, at least at the surface, is n-type. The conductivity obviously shows several distinct stages of the interaction of the reaction mixture (C3H6:air as 1:10) with the catalyst surface, namely: up to 127°C, 127–267°C, 267–390°C and above (Fig. 7). As shown in Table 1 , propylene oxidation starts to be significant above about 300°C, with carbon dioxide being the main oxidation product. Based on the Mars–van Krevelen mechanism [12]for propylene oxidation on oxide systems, the sharp increase of conductivity above this temperature can be associated with increased surface reduction [13]; this reflects increased lattice mobilisation in the catalyst surface as the reaction proceeds above 300°C. At 380°C to 400°C, some fluctuations in the propylene conversion and product distribution indicate that some surface contamination may be occurring. The lower values of conductivity revealed in the next DAr-V experiment seem to indicate that cooling the reduced oxide in the propylene/air mixture partly restores the oxidation level of the surface. Thus, it can be concluded that in the low temperature range oxidation prevails, while above 300°C the oxidation is the slower (rate-determining) step. On re-heating in dry oxygen, the conductance decreased still further (Fig. 7). Previous experiments conducted at higher temperatures (400°C to 800°C) illustrated that behaviour was p-type in this region [2]. Strong chemisorption of species for this catalyst was found to result in a loss of thermally activated conductivity [3, 4]; however in the current experiments at lower temperatures, the effects of temperature have not been much reduced by chemisorption. It is reasonable to assume that complex layered materials of this type may have surfaces substantially different in electrical characteristics from the bulk lattice. Defects at the surface will be introduced upon chemisorption and at higher temperatures different types of surface sites become activated. Temperature programmed oxidation on pre-reduced samples previously showed, using differential thermal analysis, that several significant peaks were present between 350°C and 400°C [15]. The frequency-dependent AC losses due to surface dipole effects were found in previous studies of the same catalyst to be dominant during phases of strong chemisorption and reaction, whilst reversion to thermally activated behaviour occurred during times of reduced chemical activity [3, 4]. In the case of carbon dioxide hydrogenation, the catalyst became partially reduced as a result of the chemical reaction. The corresponding changes in capacitance in the propylene–air mixture are shown in Fig. 9 . Above about 290°C, capacitance increases much more rapidly with increasing temperature as the catalytic activity starts to become significant. Here, there will be increased surface dipole activity as chemisorbed species attempt to break away from the surface, and as they do so, dipole contributions are likely to increase below the surface due to the temporary disruption of the lattice in this region. This behaviour is in contrast to that of the conductances which showed higher values over the entire temperature range. Such changes highlight the complex interplay between surface and bulk processes. Upon recycling in dry argon (DAr-V), the capacitances were lower than those in DAr-IV. Upon subsequent treatment in dry oxygen, they were further reduced as shown in Fig. 9. These results may be compared to those of conductance, all of which remained higher in the high temperature range after the propylene oxidation experiment. It is possible that some carbonaceous species had been formed on the catalyst surface, which would result in enhanced surface conductivity but have less effect on the capacitance which is dependent on processes at and below the surface. Catalytic data for different contact times (τ=catalyst volume/flow rate) and different propylene:air ratios in the feedstock are shown in Table 2 Table 3 (steady states). An increase in the flow rate (decrease in contact time) apparently results in an increased conversion (e.g. compare 365°C, Table 2). Since the conversion (estimated from the carbon balance) usually decreases as the flow rate increases (see for example [13]), the observed effect suggests kinetically controlled processes; surface contamination possibly occurs at longer contact times and a better conversion is obtained on increasing the rate of removal of the adsorbed species, i.e. on decreasing the residence time of the reactants/products on the surface. The decrease in contact time is coupled with an increase in the selectivity to partial oxidation, which suggests that consecutive oxidation of these products occurs during longer residence times. The progressive increase of the surface reduction as a result of successive testing experiments (with re-oxidation as the slower, rate-determining step) can also be the cause of the improved performance, as the anion vacancies play the role of propylene adsorption sites [13]. There is seen to be an increase in selectivity to acrolein when the ratio of propylene:air is increased (Table 3); however, the conversion remains low, and the yield is <5%. On finally treating the sample to the CO/air mixture, the conductance again increased slightly (Fig. 8) but did not rise more rapidly with increasing temperature as observed during propylene oxidation. Capacitances, however, remained close to those in dry Ar V (Fig. 9). Catalytic data for CO oxidation (Table 4 ) shows conversion at 400°C to reach 52%. Conversion increases by increasing the proportion of air in the feedstock to give a maximum of 97% conversion at 323°C for CO:air=1:35, which highlights the potential of the material as an air pollution catalyst for the removal of CO. However, on increasing the carbon monoxide concentration the gas flow became blocked probably due to excess contamination (produced by over-reduction), possibly fouling the catalyst. The possibility of surface contamination is supported by TGA on heating the used sample in air, when a weight loss of about 0.25% occurred between about 250°C and 400°C (Fig. 10 ). Many authors consider that p-type oxides are catalytically active for this reaction and maximum activity has been shown for simple Co and Ni oxides [16]. In more recent work, using highly conducting mixed oxide materials of p-type conductivity such as La–Sr–Cr–O mixtures, the catalytic activity for CO oxidation has been found to compare very favourably with more conventional supported Pt catalysts [17]. The apparent n-type behaviour at low temperatures and p-type at higher temperatures for Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ , can be a matter of surface stability as a function of temperature and atmosphere. The above conductivity data shows a temperature and history dependent behaviour, suggesting fluctuating surface properties, particularly in a reducing atmosphere. Deep reduction is possibly associated with fouling in the presence of carbon containing compounds. Recent work has shown that it may be possible to synthesise materials such as Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ at lower temperatures, (at present they are fabricated by heating over several days at temperatures between 850°C and 1000°C) [18, 19]and in future work, it should be possible to test material on a larger scale using powders with a much increased surface area. 4 Conclusions Conductance and capacitance data at 1592Hz, a frequency at which principally surface effects are likely to be revealed, during temperature programmed experiments up to 400°C show some significant changes with temperature in different atmospheres for the powdered catalyst Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ . TGA data correlated with the electrical measurements. Dry oxygen has little effect but the addition of humidity produces oscillatory behaviour in both the conductance and capacitance–temperature characteristics, up to about 200°C. In contrast, humidity results in a marked increase in the conductance in argon up to about 225°C. These results suggest that oxygen and moisture may compete for the same adsorption sites, an effect which could significantly affect catalytic behaviour. The importance of in situ electrical measurements, (in conjunction with more common characterisation techniques), in elucidating the role of water vapour has been illustrated. Propylene oxidation starts around 300°C and is accompanied by a marked increase in conductance and capacitance, as the reaction proceeds. The conductance values remained high after retesting in argon, but decreased slightly in dry oxygen, indicating some surface reduction had occurred. Capacitance values in argon were not significantly changed. Propylene conversion was low. Partial oxidation to acrolein was significantly improved by decreasing the contact time to about 0.5s, but not greatly affected by increasing the propylene:air ratio in the feedstock. Carbon monoxide was much more efficiently converted to carbon dioxide. Conversions as high as of 95% were obtained at 300°C in oxygen-rich feedstocks. This result shows the potential of the material for the catalytic removal of CO. These results illustrate links between the electrical properties of a conducting mixed oxide and its catalytic behaviour. In a similar fashion to some types of sensors, (whose conductance varies substantially with adsorbed species), the conductance of the material is history-dependent. Hence, the catalytic behaviour is also likely to depend significantly on its history. Acknowledgements The authors are grateful to the EPSRC for funding the equipment at Bradford. One of the authors (M. Caldararu) gratefully acknowledges financial support from the Royal Society for a research visit to Bradford which has made this joint paper possible. coredata.dc:description: The AC electrical properties of the mixed conducting oxide Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ at 1592Hz have been monitored during in-situ temperature programmed exposure to a sequence of dry and/or humid gaseous atmospheres between ambient and 400°C. TGA data was correlated with the electrical measurements. Dry oxygen had little effect. Humidity resulted in a significant increase in conductance and capacitance in argon but not in oxygen. Changes in conductance and capacitance arise from changes in both surface conductance and surface dipoles during chemisorption and reaction processes. Following n-type behaviour, in both propylene:air and CO:air treatments, the conductance was increased, indicating reduction of the catalyst surface. Very low conversion (<5%) was obtained for propylene (mainly to carbon dioxide), while a higher conversion (maximum of about 97%) was achieved for CO which indicates that Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ could be a possible catalyst to control pollution.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic and electrical behaviour of Li0.9Ni0.5Co0.5O2−δ below 400°C
